description: From Middle English ches, chesse, from Old French eschés, plural of eschec, from Medieval Latin scaccus, from Arabic شَاه‎ (šāh, “king [in chess]”), from Persian شاه‎ (šâh, “shah, king”), from Middle Persian 𐭬𐭫𐭪𐭠‎ (mlkʾ /šāh/)[[Category:|CHESS]], from Old Persian 𐏋 (XŠ /xšāyaθiya/).
Displaced native game and name Old English cyningtæfl ("king's board") with the continental game (common chess) and French name ("chess").
Compare German Schach and Italian scacchi. Compare French échecs (“chess”) and its descendants: Catalan escacs and Dutch schaak. More at check and shah (“king of Persia or Iran”).

entries.meaning: A board game for two players, each beginning with sixteen chess pieces moving according to fixed rules across a chessboard with the objective to checkmate the opposing king.

description: Uncertain; perhaps linked to Etymology 1, above, from the sense of being arranged in rows or lines.

entries.meaning: (now chiefly US) Any of several species of grass in the genus Bromus, generally considered weeds.

description: Compare French châssis (“a framework of carpentry”).

entries.meaning: (military, chiefly in the plural) One of the platforms, consisting of two or more planks dowelled together, for the flooring of a temporary military bridge.
examples: the balks are laid and covered with chesses to within 1 foot of the trestle
